What Students Are Expected to Do: Develop print awareness, recognize letters, understand sounds (phonemes), listen to stories, ask and answer basic questions, and express ideas through drawing, dictation, and simple writing.
Read simple texts with increasing accuracy, identify main ideas and details, build phonics and fluency, write short opinions, explanations, and narratives, and participate in structured discussions.

Read and comprehend longer literary and informational texts, quote evidence, determine themes and main ideas, write organized multi-paragraph texts, conduct short research projects, and use academic vocabulary.
Analyze complex texts across subjects, cite strong textual evidence, compare multiple sources, write arguments and explanations grounded in evidence, and engage in collaborative academic discussions.
Read increasingly complex literature and nonfiction independently, evaluate arguments and claims, write structured arguments and research-based texts, and adapt communication to audience and purpose.
Independently comprehend complex texts, synthesize information across sources, produce sustained research and analytical writing, and demonstrate command of academic language in speaking and writing.
